title: 110_hr244
content: The Act may be cited as the "Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century". The Congress finds that the value added by workers in the US and other countries is increasingly dependent on educational and training investments. There is a disparity in investment between the US and its trading partners, leading to declining educational performance in the US. This makes it challenging for US businesses to fund worker education compared to other countries. The current global workforce environment creates competitive pressures on domestic companies to utilize highly educated knowledge workers in other countries. It is in the interest of the United States government, national security, and the welfare of our Nation's workers to reverse this trend through public-private partnerships and maximizing the use of each sector's strength in training our workforce. The purpose of this Act is to encourage businesses and individuals to support the educational development of knowledge workers in the United States by providing incentives for information and communications technology education. This is crucial as the United States needs to train its workforce for high-paying technology jobs to support benefit programs for retiring baby boomers and help mature workers retrain for new jobs after retirement. The Act aims to incentivize businesses and individuals to support educational development for knowledge workers in the US, particularly in information and communications technology, engineering, and manufacturing fields. By encouraging employers to train workers in these areas, the US can better utilize training funds and enhance the skills of newly trained individuals. SEC. 30D. INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY EDUCATION AND TRAINING PROGRAM EXPENSES. The text discusses a tax credit for information and communications technology education and training program expenses. The credit allows for 50% of expenses paid by the taxpayer for the benefit of employees or individuals, with a limit of $4,000 per individual. The tax credit for information and communications technology education and training program expenses has a limit of $4,000 per individual, which can be increased to $5,000 for certain programs and individuals in specific designated areas or school districts. Schools in eligible districts can receive free or reduced-cost lunches under the school lunch program. This includes areas designated as disaster areas, rural enterprise communities, and Rural Economic areas by the Secretary of Agriculture. The Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999 provides for information technology education and training program expenses for individuals with disabilities in designated rural areas or under tribal jurisdiction. The term 'information technology education and training program expenses' refers to costs incurred for participating in relevant programs, including coursework, certification testing, and other essential expenses. These programs focus on information and communications technology disciplines and skill development in the United States. The term 'training program' refers to education in information and communications technology provided by accredited institutions or employers. Commercial and employer-owned organizations offer industry-recognized training programs. The company provides IT training to employees using internal personnel, following industry standards. No double benefits allowed for expenses, and rules from other sections apply. The credit for training expenses should not exceed certain limits. The credit for training expenses should not exceed certain limits, with rules similar to section 45A(e)(2) and subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 52 applying. The credit allowed for any taxable year should not exceed the excess of the regular tax reduced by other credits over the tentative minimum tax for the year. The amendments made by this section apply to amounts paid or incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. Eligible educational institution. SEC. 4 amends the definition of an eligible educational institution to include institutions under the Higher Education Act of 1965 or commercial information and communications technology training providers. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2006. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board is established with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Board develops guidelines for computer science and information technology courses and certifications for approval by the Secretary. Meetings are held at least annually, and a Chairperson is elected from among the members who are not federal government employees. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board develops guidelines for college courses and certifications in science and information technology. The Board submits a list of approved certifications to the Secretary of the Treasury annually. Board members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Board is not subject to termination under the Federal Advisory Committee Act.
